senses.note: This word refers to all species except flicker, and descriptions of the kookóóxee given around 1950 suggest it may have been a sapsucker.

3.cultural: Because of their yellow/orange color, Kestrel feathers were used in the Peyote Ceremony similarly to Flicker Feathers (Kroeber, The Arapaho, p. 407).

senses.note: This word is perhaps used more generally for other similar marsh and shorebirds. See Mountain Plover.

Kroeber says the bird was imitated in the Peyote Ceremony. The term for ‘crying’ is more specifically a word for whimpering, feeling pitiful or sorry for oneself and so forth, often translated as ‘crying around’ by Northern Arapahos – as opposed to intense but brief crying.

9.literal: it has a large white bill

senses.definition: heron, egret, esp. the Great Blue Heron
fly in circles, soar in circles (e.g. a bird)

16.gloss: to fly in circles, to soar in circles (e.g. a bird)

senses.definition: woodpecker, esp. hairy or downy woodpeckers

18.gloss: woodpecker, esp. hairy or downy woodpeckers

senses.note: The final -hin is unclear in origin, unless it is meant to be kookooxeehi’ (diminutive).

21.literal: the one who uses dirt (to build its nest)

senses.note: This term refers especially to Cliff Swallows, who build their nests from mud and dirt. Other swallow species nest in tree holes or dirt banks, but the name is used for all types of swallows.
This word is more properly used only for cranes, but is extended by many people to all large, tall, long-legged wading birds.
Refers especially to hens (C&M-TM)

senses.definition: singers/drummers at a ceremonial event (ceremonial term)

senses.note: The ending of this word is a diminutive suffix, meaning “little one.”

senses.definition: have webbed feet (as a duck) 3 changed see'eihteet

33.gloss: have flat feet; have webbed feet

senses.note: This name was provided by Mark Soldierwolf. He said they are called ‘ghosts’ because of the strange sound they make at night after they enter their nests. His description seemed to be first or all oriented towards Cliff Swallows. This word corresponds in part to the Gros Ventre word for cliff swallow, which is biitei-wosish or biitei-bii3os’i.

senses.definition: young (without the white head and tail) bald eagle

36.cultural: A widely known story tells how the nighthawk came to have such a big mouth. Nighthawks were also seen as indicative of rain, since they fly before thunderstorms (Kroeber, The Arapaho, p. 434).

senses.note: This word is apparently an imitation of the bird’s call.

The name for this bird corresponds to the term used to describe the ‘trilling’ or ‘yodeling’ which women singers do on various ceremonial occasions - at funerals, for example, or at the Sun Dance. The sound of the bird as it does its descending courtship flight and call is viewed as similar to the sound the women make.
Kroeber (mss 2560, 5:78) notes that this bird was not involved with the Peyote Ceremony (or probably any other ceremonies) because it’s red head was believed to be due to hemorrhaging of the lungs.
This word can apparently be used for any long-legged wading bird of any size (see Rails).
senses.definition: also perhaps curlew, slough bird, rail or other birds with long, thin legs

senses.note: Modern singular form is siisííko'.
senses.usage: Obsolete. Recorded by Gatschet and Kroeber in OK, 1900 and earlier.

senses.note: This is the name collected by FV Hayden in 1863 for a bird he identifies as Charadrius montana - the Mountain Plover. However, he translates the term as ‘scar bird,’ which is incorrect, and also identifies the bird as having spots on its head which look like scars. He may have been confused as to the correct identification. His bird names are notably suspicious: he gives the translation ‘spotted wing’ for beescénee (wild turkey) when the actual translation is ‘big grouse.’

52.literal: the warm who brings the warm season

senses.note: This word describes the bird’s mating call: biicei’i. This imitation of the sound also means ‘it is summer/warm season’ in Arapaho, and thus the chickadee’s mating call is seen as a sign of coming spring by Arapahos.

This word was given by Mark Soldierwolf. He could not remember the exact name, but said it was composed of the two elements above, the first of which he said means ‘pinyon pine’. Since pinyons are absent from Wyoming and northern Colorado, the tree in question is most likely Limber Pine (though this word is otherwise undocumented), with Whitebark Pine being a less likely possibility. Nutcrackers feed heavily on Limber Pine seeds.

senses.definition: area to the west of Thunder Pass in RMNP, near Sawtooth Peak

57.cultural: Flicker feathers were/are extremely important in the Peyote Ceremony. This seems to have been especially true of the Yellow-Shafted Flicker of Oklahoma, where the Arapahos first began practicing the Ghost Dance. The color yellow is especially associated with the Peyote Ceremony, and thus the Flicker became a key bird. Flickers also appear in older myths, such as that of Little Star (Dorsey, p. 224), so their importance predates the Peyote Ceremony (Kr 2560, 5:78). Their feathers were used in war implements, to bring swiftness (Kroeber, The Arapaho, p. 432).

senses.note: The name comes from the way in which this owl turns its head completely around, as if it has a broken neck.

senses.definition: Northern Arapaho Eagle Drum (the main ceremonial drum of the tribe); the appointed drummers are included in this term collectively as well.
(with plural) the drummers appointed to perform with the ceremonial Eagle Drum (as distinct from the drum itself)

63.literal: the one who eats bad things

senses.note: The first part of this word could also be partly based on a description of the call that ravens make. See ‘chickadee’ for a similar name which, though meaningful in Arapaho, also imitates the call of the bird.
Modern singular form is né'ii.

This term is also an old word for “god” or “man-above,” which dates from prior to White contact. The Crow is the messenger from and guide to the world beyond, in some accounts (Kroeber, The Arapaho, p. 347).

66.cultural: The Crow was and is extremely important in Arapaho ceremony. The Crow Dance, which was a later derivation of the Ghost Dance, featured the Crow as the central emblem, and Crow feathers were widely used in both the Ghost and Crow Dances for making ceremonial items.

senses.definition: bluebird, blue jay, stellar's jay, pinyon jay

68.gloss: bluebird; blue jay; Blue Bird (myth character)

senses.note: The name derives from the idea that coots have bugs in their stomach that help digest of grind up their food.
senses.sources: Cowell ms; Edward Willow and Howard Antelope

70.cultural: This is the “packed bird” referred to in the Arapaho origin myth and Sun Dance story (Dorsey, p. 195).

74.literal: it dives head-first; it is a fish killer
74.cultural:
The Kingfisher was one of the birds that dived unsuccessfully for land at the time of the creation of the Dry Land (Dorsey, p. 194).
The Kingfisher was admired as a powerful bird because of the way it swoops and strikes at its prey. Kingfisher hides, feathers or dried flesh were carried into battle for this reason (see Kroeber, The Arapaho, p. 440, for example).
The Kingfisher also played an important role in the Crow Dance (the later version of the Ghost Dance). Part of this ceremony was called the Kingfisher Dance.

77.cultural: The magpie ranks just behind the Eagle as perhaps the most important of all birds for the Arapaho in ceremonial uses. It was admired for its handsome appearance and swift flight, and especially for the way it bravely flew into camp and made off with food, like a successful Indian raider. Its feathers were not used that often in more traditional ceremonies, despite the general admiration, but they were very widely used in creating ritual objects used in the Ghost Dance.

senses.note: This word was given by Mark Soldierwolf for both Sharp-shinned and Cooper’s Hawks.

The name for this bird corresponds to the term used to describe the ‘trilling’ or ‘yodeling’ which women singers do on various ceremonial occasions - at funerals, for example, or at the Sun Dance. The sound of the bird as it does its descending courtship flight and call is viewed as similar to the sound the women make.
Commonly translated into English as "Jack Frost."
senses.definition: used figuratively to refer to snowy weather or frost

83.cultural: There is also a mythical figure known as White Owl, who is the eternal adversary of the Thunderbird. White Owl represents night, winter, snow and cold, while Thunderbird represents day, summer, rain, and heat.

84.cultural: In the origin myth of the Flat Pipe and the Creation of the Earth, the “Red-Head Duck” succeeds in bringing up the earth to create dry land (Dorsey, p. 197-98). The only two red-headed diving ducks in North America are the Common Redhead and the Canvasback, so one of these species is the one in question.

senses.definition: a large rock formation on the road from Ft. Collins to Estes Park

85.gloss: rock formation between Ft. Collins and Estes Park
